I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Strategy 2020 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) highlights regional integration as 
one  of  the  three  complementary  strategic  agenda,  along  with  inclusive  growth  and 
environmentally sustainable growth.1 Under the regional integration agenda, ADB is mainly 
undertaking four roles: (i) increasing financial resources for regional cooperation and integration 
(RCI) projects, (ii) expanding the dissemination of RCI-related knowledge products, (iii) building 
the institutional capacity of developing member countries (DMCs) to manage RCI, and (iv) 
working as a catalyst and coordinator for closer cooperation among regional member countries. 
Following the launch of Strategy 2020 in 2008, and supported by the adoption of the RCI 
Strategy in 2006, RCI has become fully integrated as a strategic and operational pillar in most 
country  partnership  strategies. 2  ADB’s  Midterm  Review  of  Strategy  2020  continues  to 
underscore the RCI agenda, with support for RCI accounting for 22% of overall volume of ADB 
operations during 2013–2015.3 ADB is working to meet the target of at least 30% by 2020. 
 
2.  The Regional Cooperation and Integration Division (ERCI) plays an important role in 
supporting ADB’s mandate to promote RCI through its (i) knowledge products and services such 
as the Asian Economic Integration Report (AEIR), (ii) support for regional and global policy 
forums, and (iii) generation and maintenance of RCI-related data and research in support of 
ADB’s RCI operations. Building on the success of previous technical assistance (TA) projects 
supporting  the  Asia  Regional Integration  Center (ARIC),4 the TA  will  extend  ERCI’s major 
research and knowledge work with a heightened focus on the following areas: (i) strengthening 
the quality and impact of the AEIR, (ii) enhancing ADB’s profile as a knowledge leader and DMC 
partner on RCI through effective support for ADB participation in regional and global policy 
forums, and (iii) improving the quality of the RCI database and policy analysis. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The region faces growing challenges amid sluggish global economic recovery and a 
slowdown  in  regional  economic  growth,  which  could  undermine  the  sustained  growth

ADB through its Office of Regional Economic Integration (currently known as ERCI) to (i) provide access to timely

(iii) support research on RCI. Previous TA projects that supported the creation and maintenance of the ARIC and 
its precursor, the Asia Recovery Information Center, include the following: ADB. 1999. Technical Assistance for the 
Establishment of the Asia Recovery Information Center. Manila (TA 5848-REG); ADB. 2001. Technical Assistance 
for the Asia Recovery Information Center, Phase II. Manila (TA 5981-REG); ADB. 2003. Technical Assistance for 
the Asia Recovery Information Center, Phase III. Manila (TA 6138-REG); ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for the 
Asia Regional Integration Center. Manila (TA 6314-REG); ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance for the Asia Regional 
Integration Center, Phase II. Manila (TA 6459-REG); ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance for the Asia Regional 
Integration Center, Phase III. Manila (TA 7396-REG); ADB. 2011. Technical Assistance for the Asia Regional 
Integration Center, Phase IV. Manila (TA 7913-REG); ADB. 2013. Technical Assistance for the Asia Regional 
Integration Center, Phase V. Manila (TA 8533-REG). 
5  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 18 April 2016.

2 
momentum of the region and further progress in poverty reduction.6 These challenges include (i) 
the steep decline and volatility of commodity prices, which negatively affect regional commodity-
exporting economies; (ii) the widening divergence in monetary policy stance among the world’s 
developed economies, which poses the potential risk of capital flow reversal in the region; and 
(iii)  a  slowdown  of  regional  trade growth,  which  could  exacerbate  a  slowdown  in  regional 
economic  growth  further.  A  fast-changing  global  and  regional  economic  environment  and 
associated  challenges  underscore  the  importance  of  closer  economic  cooperation  and 
integration for the region’s sustained and stable growth. 
 
4.  Regional integration helps (i) unlock growth potential for Asia and the Pacific by (a) 
creating common regional markets through reducing barriers to trade, finance, and investment 
flows, and (b) enhancing cross-border connectivity; (ii) mobilize regional savings for regional 
investments; and (iii) reduce macroeconomic and financial vulnerability to shocks. Meanwhile, 
regional cooperation helps fend off potential risks of financial instability and forge effective policy 
responses to contain spillover risks. This is especially important since the need to manage the 
risks from increased interdependencies and spillovers from negative shocks originating both 
inside and outside the region is becoming increasingly crucial. 
 
5.  RCI is gaining some traction in Asia and the Pacific. For instance, intraregional trade 
share remains stable at around 55% since 2002. From 2010 to 2014, the region’s outward 
foreign direct investments (FDIs) increased by 45.3% to $512 billion, and intraregional FDI is 
estimated at $255 billion in 2014, accounting for 52.6% of total inflows.7 On portfolio capital 
flows, intraregional outward portfolio shares—for both equity and debt—increased from 18.7% 
in 2013 to 19.5% in 2014 even though the region was and remains more integrated with global 
markets than with regional markets. Free trade agreements (FTAs) continue to proliferate: 
cumulatively, 151 FTAs had been concluded by 2015, up from 45 in 2000.8 In addition, dynamic 
developments in the RCI policy arena are taking place—including the signing of the Trans-
Pacific Partnership among 12 members in February 2016,9 and progress in negotiations of the 
Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership10—that will significantly change the economic 
and policy environment for trade and investments among economies in the region. The region’s 
production network has also strengthened and become increasingly interwoven with the global 
production network over the past decades.  A deepening global value chain has significant 
implications on the changing trade and investment pattern, which requires appropriate policy 
responses. It can widen the wedge between statutory tariffs and actual tariff costs, for example. 
 
6.  All  these  developments  call  for  deeper  analysis  on  how  regional  integration  is 
progressing through trade and investments, financial interconnectedness, and movement of 
people, and how regional cooperation can help in promoting inclusive and sustainable growth,

supplementing national policies, strengthening regional financial safety nets, and buttressing 
social and environmental protection. 
 
7.  The  fast-changing  economic  environment  and  emerging  challenges  require  policy 
makers in the region to stay vigilant in monitoring developments in regional economic issues 
and forging appropriate policy responses nationally as well as regionally. Various regional and 
global forums, such as the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, the Association of Southeast 
Asian Nations (ASEAN), ASEAN+3,11 Asia–Europe Meeting, and East Asia Summit, all aim to 
discuss policy measures to respond to and address growing challenges, and maximize mutual 
benefits through concerted actions and cooperation among regional economies. In tandem with 
this, ADB’s knowledge support role for these regional policy forums through relevant research 
and analytical work is becoming increasingly important. 
 
III.  THE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact will be enhanced awareness of RCI and how to leverage it for inclusive and 
sustainable growth in Asia and the Pacific. The outcome will be  the creation of new  RCI 
knowledge, policy options, and strategic suggestions to address pressing regional economic 
and  development  issues,  which  will  be  shared  in  various  regional  forums  and  with  key 
stakeholders. The outcome will be measured through the number of high-quality, high-impact 
knowledge products and events on major RCI issues, reflected in the number of media citations 
and interviews, use of ARIC data and information in management speeches, and utilization of 
data and information by internal and external clients from the ARIC website. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The outputs will include (i) key RCI publications and knowledge products, such as the 
AEIR and biannual confidential notes (reports on economic prospects and policy issues) for 
ASEAN+3; and (ii) timely generation of accurate RCI indicators and database, which will provide 
effective research and data support for ADB management’s participation in regional and global 
policy forums, and an information service for external clients, both in the policy arena and 
academia. 
 
10.  These outputs will be delivered through the following key activities: 
(i)  Generation of key regional cooperation and integration publications and 
knowledge products. In addition to providing updates on RCI progress in the areas of 
trade and investments, financial integration, movement of people, and trade policy, the 
AEIR will feature high-quality thematic chapters on recent and/or impending challenges 
and  issues  (e.g.,  FDI,  macroeconomic  and  financial  vulnerabilities  and 
interconnectedness, global and regional value chains, and people mobility). In support of 
the ASEAN+3 meetings, reports on regional economic outlook and risks, as well as RCI 
progress  on  trade  and  financial  integration,  will  also  be  prepared  in  time  for  the 
semiannual ASEAN+3 finance and central bank deputies’ meetings. The TA will also 
strengthen support for ADB’s RCI operations through knowledge generation on RCI-
related  issues,  such  as  regional  trade  and  investment,  financial  cooperation  and 
integration, regional connectivity, and regional public goods. Stronger coordination with 
ADB’s operations departments will be pursued in terms of selection of research topics 
                                                
11 ASEAN members plus the People’s Republic of China, Japan, and the Republic of Korea.

4 
and  use  of  appropriate  methodologies  for  better  relevance  of  knowledge  work  to 
operational needs. Research focus will be guided by the RCI strategy, with priority given 
to topics that are highlighted during regional and global policy forums, and to emerging 
issues where research could contribute to fruitful discussions among policy makers, with 
due consideration of regional knowledge solutions covered in ADB’s regional knowledge 
plans. Given the scale and increasing frequency of climate-related and other natural 
hazards, and the serious damage they cause, studies on regional public goods will be 
explored  in  consultation  with  ADB’s  operations  departments  and  Sustainable 
Development  and  Climate  Change  Department.  The  TA’s  operational  support  also 
includes  conducting  the  annual  survey  of trade finance  in  collaboration  with  ADB’s 
Private Sector Operations Department. 
 
(ii)  Maintenance of regional cooperation and integration databases. The TA will 
continue to provide a timely and accurate macroeconomic and financial database, a 
regional integration indicators database (i.e., finance, trade, labor mobility, and FDI); an 
FTA database and tool kit; and an early warning system database, which can be used by 
stakeholders inside and outside ADB, practitioners, and academia to help their policy- 
and research-related work. Enhancements will be made to make these databases user-
friendly and easy to access. 
 
(iii)  Dissemination of key regional cooperation and integration information and 
knowledge products. To present the key findings of the AEIR, the TA will organize and 
conduct both internal and external AEIR launches and seminars in collaboration with 
ADB’s regional departments and Department of External Relations. Outreach programs 
will target DMC officials, global and regional think tanks and opinion leaders, and other 
stakeholders. AEIR copies will be made available both in print and online formats. 
Effective  dissemination  of  RCI  knowledge  products  will  also  be  pursued  through 
international conferences and seminars in collaboration with research institutions. The 
TA will use social media platforms, such as Facebook and Twitter, to disseminate the 
TA’s outputs. Blog entries will be posted on the ARIC website to feature RCI issues and 
topics and raise awareness on emerging challenges and priorities. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,200,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). The detailed cost estimates and financing 
plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  The TA will be implemented over 26 months from June 2016 to July 2018. ADB will be 
the executing agency. The TA will be implemented by ERCI with support from other divisions of 
ADB’s Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department and other ADB departments, 
offices,  and  thematic  groups,  particularly  the  RCI  thematic  group.  For  possible  research 
collaboration  and  joint  conferences  and  dissemination  activities  based  on  their  areas  of 
expertise and research interests, the TA will also identify and partner with suitable centers of 
excellence12 in the region or globally. 
                                                
12 Centers of excellence are “renowned knowledge providers outside and within Asia and the Pacific (including in 
DMCs) with whom ADB could partner for knowledge solutions.” Source: ADB. 2013. Knowledge Management 
Directions and Action Plan (2013–2015): Supporting “Finance ++” at the Asian Development Bank. Manila.

5 
13.  The TA will require approximately 5 person-months of international consulting services, 
268 person-months of national consulting services, and 5 person-months of resource persons. 
All consultants will be selected and engaged individually by ADB in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). For this TA, hiring 
a  team  of  individual  consultants  will  provide  more  benefits for  ADB than  engaging  a firm 
because of the following reasons: (i) faster mobilization of consultants, (ii) greater control by 
ADB  staff  in  selecting  and  managing  individual  consultants,  and  (iii)  greater  flexibility  in 
engaging experts specializing in a broad spectrum of RCI-related topics that need to quickly 
adjust to evolving needs of stakeholders. 
 
14.  A team of ERCI staff comprising at least three international staff members (one of them 
acting as the project leader as well as the leader of the team of consultants, one national officer, 
and one operations assistant) will oversee and lead the implementation of the TA. For the 
production of research outcomes, including the AEIR, the team will organize internal seminars 
and workshops, which will include operations department experts as resource persons, as 
appropriate, to gather feedback and inputs. An international consultant will be hired to edit ERCI 
publications and speeches as well as ARIC website content. National consultants will include a 
principal economic analyst, who will provide coordination support to ARIC’s operations; four 
senior economic analysts, who will lead the delivery of ARIC’s core outputs, including the AEIR; 
and three economic analysts and a statistician, who will maintain and update the contents of the 
ARIC website and database, and assist in the preparation of ARIC publications and seminars. 
Other national consultants include one full-time system and database developer. One website 
developer and one multimedia designer and developer will also be engaged on an intermittent 
basis. About 18 resource persons who are internationally distinguished experts will be engaged 
for  5  person-months  to  present  or  facilitate  discussions  at  seminars  and  other  events.  A 
typesetter, who will be sourced from the Department of External Relations list of accredited 
service providers, will be responsible for the typesetting and page layout of the AEIR. Appendix 
3 provides the outline terms of reference for consultants. 
 
15.  Purchases of equipment (computer hardware and software) and statistical databases will 
be undertaken in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2015, as amended from time 
to time) and in coordination with ADB’s Office of Information Systems and Technology and 
Office of Administrative Services, where applicable. After the TA is completed, any procured 
equipment  will  be  disposed  of  in  compliance  with  Administering  Grant-Financed  Technical 
Assistance Projects in the Project Administration Instructions.13 Disbursements under this TA 
will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, 
as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,200,000 on a grant basis 
for the Asian Economic Integration: Building Knowledge for Policy Dialogue project, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

Economics,  CEIC  Data,  Haver  Analytics, World  Trade  Online,  United  Nations World  Tourism  Organization 
database, and Bloomberg. 
Source: ADB estimates.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  To implement the technical assistance (TA) project, the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
through the Regional Cooperation and Integration Division (ERCI) of its Economic Research 
and Regional Cooperation Department, will require 273 person-months of consultant inputs, 
including one individual international consultant to edit the knowledge outputs produced under 
the TA, nine individual national consultants to provide analytical and research support, and 
three individual national consultants to help manage and develop the Asia Regional Integration 
Center (ARIC) website. ERCI, which will coordinate TA implementation, will be responsible for 
providing overall research guidance and consolidating the research outputs of the individual 
consultants. Wherever possible, ERCI will also engage in collaborative research with other 
divisions and departments within ADB. 
 
A.  Individual International Consultant 
 
2.  Economics and copy editor (1 position, 5 person-months). The editor, preferably with 
15 years of relevant work experience, should be familiar with economic and development issues 
in Asia and the Pacific, and have strong communication skills. The consultant is expected to edit 
the ARIC website, management statements, press releases, ERCI publications, and technical 
documents; and write comments on the substance and logic of arguments and outputs to 
ensure compliance with ADB style and usage. Under the supervision of ADB staff, the editor will 
(i)  edit the contents of the ARIC website, the Asian Economic Integration Report 
(AEIR), press releases, management speeches, and technical documents; 
(ii)  examine economic arguments in the documents to assess whether they are 
logical and are based on accepted economic theory and principles, and revise 
them, if necessary; 
(iii)  examine  and  edit  the  tables  and  figures  in  the  documents  to  support  data 
consistency; 
(iv)  provide support to ERCI in preparing management speeches; and 
(v)  ensure that documents adhere to ADB style and usage and conform to high 
publication standards. 
 
B.  Individual National Consultants 
 
3.  Principal  economic  analyst  (1 position, 24 person-months). The analyst will have 
sufficient  managerial  capabilities  to  perform  supervisory  tasks,  extensive  knowledge  of 
economic and policy issues in the region, adequate background on database development and 
management,  strong  proficiency  in  data  processing  and  analysis,  familiarity  with  computer 
applications used in economic analysis, and good communication skills. The analyst, preferably 
with 8 years of relevant work experience, will work on a daily basis at ADB headquarters and 
will report to the project leader and/or other TA members. Under the supervision of the project 
leader and/or TA members, the analyst will 
(i)  coordinate with other TA members in the absence of the project leader, 
(ii)  assist in the management of the daily operations of ARIC, 
(iii)  help the project leader and/or other TA members implement the ARIC work plan, 
(iv)  assist in the supervision of technical work done by the consultants engaged 
under this TA, 
(v)  support  the  project  leader  and/or  other  TA  members  in  the  preparation  of 
management reports related to ARIC, 
(vi)  liaise with ADB departments and other stakeholders on ARIC-related matters,

Appendix 3  11 
(vii)  provide research support in the preparation of the AEIR by providing country 
notes and data assistance, 
(viii)  execute data and research requests from ERCI management, and 
(ix)  provide other technical support as may be requested by the project leader and/or 
other TA members. 
 
4.  Senior economic analysts (4 positions, 96 person-months total). The analysts, each 
engaged for 24 person-months, will manage and supervise the delivery of ARIC’s core services: 
(i) website and database updating, (ii) regional economic monitoring, and (iii) research and 
modeling. The analysts, preferably with 6 years of relevant work experience each, will have 
technical knowledge in terms of information technology and programming, economic and policy 
issues, and economic modeling. The analysts will work on a daily basis at ADB headquarters 
and will report to the principal economic analyst, project leader, and/or other TA members. 
Under the supervision of the project leader and/or other TA members, the analysts will 
(i)  assist in the delivery of outputs under ARIC’s core services, 
(ii)  review the work done by the other national consultants engaged under this TA, 
(iii)  lead the preparation of the regional cooperation and integration (RCI)-related 
knowledge products under this TA, 
(iv)  lead the preparation of the AEIR and other ERCI publications supported by ARIC, 
(v)  lead the preparation of macroeconomic and financial monitoring reports (daily 
and weekly), 
(vi)  prepare macroeconomic reports on assigned Asian economies as inputs to ERCI 
policy reports and publications, 
(vii)  provide data and editorial assistance to other ERCI publications, 
(viii)  provide logistical and coordination support to ERCI seminars, website promotion, 
and other activities as requested by ADB staff, and 
(ix)  provide other research and general administrative and technical support as may 
be requested by the project leader and/or other TA members. 
 
5.  Economic analysts (3 positions, 72 person-months total). The analysts, each engaged 
for 24 person-months, will help the TA operate the ARIC website, develop and update indicators, 
provide data assistance, and prepare the AEIR. The analysts, preferably with 3 years of relevant 
work experience each, will have extensive experience in economic, social, and financial data 
processing and analysis; be familiar with issues concerning RCI; have strong communication 
skills; and be proficient in using standard computer applications and software. The analysts will 
work on a daily basis at ADB headquarters and will report to the principal economic analyst, 
project leader, and/or other TA members. Under the supervision of the project leader and/or 
other TA members, the analysts will 
(i)  maintain, develop, and contribute to the enhancement of the following sections of 
the website: 
(a)  RCI pillars (money and finance, trade and investment, infrastructure and 
software, regional public goods); 
(b)  RCI integration indicators and databases; 
(c)  economic and financial indicators; 
(d)  early warning system database; 
(e)  trade finance survey results; and 
(f)  other sections as may be required; 
(ii)  support the operation and development of the ARIC website; 
(iii)  assist in conceptualizing website design and front-end user tools and preparing 
requirements for content management systems (CMSs);

12  Appendix 3 
(iv)  prepare  RCI-related  knowledge  products,  including  RCI  digest  and  country 
profiles on RCI indicators; 
(v)  assist in the preparation of the AEIR and other ERCI publications; 
(vi)  prepare daily and weekly macroeconomic and financial monitoring reports; 
(vii)  prepare macroeconomic reports on assigned Asian economies as inputs to ERCI 
policy reports and publications; 
(viii)  provide data and editorial assistance to AEIR and other publications produced 
under this TA; 
(ix)  provide logistical and coordination support to RCI seminars organized by ERCI, 
website promotion, and other activities as requested by ADB staff; and 
(x)  provide other research and general administrative and technical support as may 
be requested by the project leader and/or other TA members. 
 
6.  Statistician (1 position, 24 person-months). The statistician will help the TA operate the 
ARIC website, develop and update indicators, provide data assistance, and prepare the AEIR. 
The statistician will have extensive experience in economic and financial data processing and 
analysis,  preferably  for  5  years;  strong  communication  skills;  ability  to  coordinate  with 
government offices and data providers that deal with national or global statistics, if needed; and 
advanced skills in gathering data, and proficiency in using software with standard applications. 
The statistician will be working on a daily basis at ADB headquarters and will report to the 
principal economic analyst, project leader, and/or other TA members. Under the supervision of 
the project leader and/or other TA members, the statistician will: 
(i)  collect and process economic and financial data; 
(ii)  liaise with other national consultants engaged under this TA in processing and 
analyzing the data; 
(iii)  provide support in maintaining the early warning system database; 
(iv)  assist in the preparation of the AEIR and other ERCI publications; 
(v)  provide logistical and coordination support to RCI seminars organized by ERCI, 
website promotion, and other activities as requested by ADB staff; and 
(vi)  provide other research and general administrative and technical support as may 
be requested by the project leader and/or other TA members. 
 
7.  System  and  database  developer  (1 position, 24 person-months). The system and 
database developer, preferably with 10 years of relevant work experience, will help the project 
leader and/or other TA members expand, improve, and operate the ARIC website. The system 
and database developer will work on a daily basis at ADB headquarters and will report to the 
principal economic analyst, project leader, and/or other TA members. Under the supervision of 
the project leader and/or other TA members, the system and database developer will 
(i)  improve  the  CMS  for  the  macroeconomic  and  financial  indicators  database, 
including adding new functions to the front-end website interface of the user-
defined section of the database; 
(ii)  revise the CMS for the regional integration indicators database, including adding 
new functions to facilitate inputs of various types of datasets and creating new 
outputs needed for website uploads and research; 
(iii)  improve the CMS for the early warning system database, including 
(a)  adding  more  fields  and  functions  to  accommodate  more  countries  and 
additional vulnerability indicators, and 
(b)  merging the early warning system database with the macroeconomic and 
financial database for easy updating; 
(iv)  maintain and upgrade the free trade agreement (FTA) database CMS, including 
adding a user-defined interface;

14  Appendix 3 
9.  Multimedia designer and developer (1 position, 10 person-months). The multimedia 
designer and developer, preferably with 8 years of relevant work experience, will help the 
project leader and/or other TA members operate, improve, and expand the ARIC website by 
undertaking graphic design work of web pages to be created. The consultant will work on an 
intermittent basis at ADB headquarters and will report to the principal economic analyst, project 
leader, and/or other TA members. Under the supervision of the project leader and/or other TA 
members, the multimedia designer and developer will 
(i)  conceptualize designs and develop front-end templates for the ARIC website and 
pages; 
(ii)  manage and update static content for the ARIC website and pages; 
(iii)  conceptualize and execute design, including icons and thumbnails of new web 
pages; 
(iv)  carry out other tasks related to web graphical design as assigned by the project 
leader and/or other TA members;  
(v)  provide support to ARIC on site uploads and editing support for all ARIC online 
and/or print materials; 
(vi)  conceptualize and implement designs for ARIC and ERCI promotional materials; 
(vii)  provide layout services to various ARIC documents and ERCI publications; 
(viii)  coordinate with relevant departments to ensure that the graphic design work of 
the website is consistent with ADB design guidelines; 
(ix)  provide photography and video production support, edit video materials, convert 
files to various formats, produce compact disc and/or DVD materials, prepare 
cover design, and assist ARIC with local events and reproduction requests; and 
(x)  provide other publication support as may be requested by the project leader 
and/or other TA members. 
 
C.  Resource Persons 
 
10.  Resource persons (about 18 positions, 5 person-months total). Each resource person 
will be engaged for not more than 10 working days to make presentations at RCI seminars and 
conferences, and/or AEIR launches, seminars, and workshops. The resource persons will be 
internationally distinguished experts or policy makers specializing on RCI issues. The resource 
persons will 
(i)  conduct presentations on the topics assigned to them; and 
(ii)  moderate and facilitate discussions and exchanges of ideas among participants, 
as well as with other resource persons.
